Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Paradigm Shift in Vector Control: Targeted Larvicides
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will be a significant improvement in the control of dangerous mosquitoes that transmit serious diseases to humans, including Zika fever, malaria, encephalitis, chikungunya, and dengue fever. This project will generate a novel larvicide directed against the larvae of harmful mosquitoes that live in water. The larvicide is combined with an efficient lure to generate effective bait-and-kill stations that will target only harmful mosquito species. An efficient, inexpensive, safe product to kill mosquito larvae will improve public health since it will greatly reduce the number of adult mosquitoes capable of infecting humans with diseases. The product will protect non-target species and will not contaminate the water with toxins. This project incorporates several new technologies that are also applicable to the future control of other insect pest species, including a novel design system to produce lures that attract mosquito larvae to bait stations, a new method to kill insect larvae while leaving other species unharmed, and a new method to package the control product. The product and the methods discussed are new, address unmet health and safety needs in several countries, and are expected to have widespread market appeal.

The technical objectives in this Phase I research project are focused on providing novel attractants for the aquatic larvae of Aedes aegypti and other harmful mosquitos, and combining these lures with a novel larvicide that will eradicate the targeted larvae without contaminating the water column with insecticide or harming non-target species. The mosquito?s range is expanding and traditional control methods are becoming problematic. An effective bait-and-kill device would avoid the wide dispersal of broad-range insecticides and protect the environment, beneficial species, and humans. However, this device requires an efficient attractant to selectively lure mosquito larvae and an effectual, yet selective, larvicide that will not harm non-target species or contaminate the water. These are therefore the foci of this project. This project incorporates several novel approaches to develop a microencapsulated nanoparticle that will function as a targeted larvicide. To achieve the stated goals, compounds that strongly attract mosquito larvae will be combined with a nonpoisonous polymer larvicide that is active only uponingestion by the larvae. The anticipated end product is a bait-and-kill device for A. aegypti larvae that would allow a shift away from broad-spectrum insecticides to a more targeted, responsible control methodology. The platform technologies are applicable to other species in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mosquitoes are responsible for the transmission of numerous diseases to humans. For example, several mosquito species transmit diseases including Zika fever, malaria, encephalitis, chikungunya, and dengue fever. The infirm, the elderly, and children are most at risk, and mosquito-borne diseases continue to claim millions of lives globally despite concerted control efforts. Although mosquito-borne diseases are more prominent in the developing world, a number of factors ranging from international travel to climate change have placed the developed world at increased risk for mosquito-borne disease epidemics. Various control methods, including insecticides, bed nets, transgenic mosquitoes, and repellents have concentrated on limiting adult mosquito populations. However, the mosquito life cycle includes aquatic stages that have not been targeted to the same extent as airborne adults. Public health would benefit from effective, practical products to control aquatic larvae.

This project has therefore pursued novel control methods for the larvae of the mosquito species, Culex pipiens, and other harmful mosquitoes with similar life cycles. The larvae of disease vectors such as Aedes spp., Anopheles spp., and Culex spp. develop – and crucially, feed – in bodies of water. In many instances these bodies of water serve as a source of food and potable water for humans and/or support complex ecosystems comprising a variety of aquatic and terrestrial species in intricate food webs; these complications pose challenges in terms of safely and effectively distributing a larval control product in the water column and counter-indicate the use of broad-spectrum insecticides in favor of more carefully aimed solutions. To address safety, efficacy, and ecological concerns this project implemented a multi-faceted, unique approach to larval control encompassing innovative bait-and-kill stations that preferentially attract mosquito larvae, remain mostly inert if ingested by non-targeted species, and have low toxicity, yet selectively kill mosquito larvae upon ingestion. To achieve these goals the bait-and-kill stations require the development of a microencapsulated nanoparticle that acts as a targeted mosquito larvicide and combines an efficient larval attractant to selectively lure mosquito larvae with a nontoxic polymer that acts as a killing agent only upon ingestion by mosquitoes.

The broader impact of this research is that the methodologies used to generate microencapsulated nanoparticle larvocides are novel platform technologies. These platform technologies have the potential to improve public health by exploiting life cycle stages that were previously relatively inaccessible in order to reduce vector population sizes. Moreover, the approach offers increased environmental protection and guards bodies of water that are significant environmental resources from excessive contamination by toxins.

The results and technologies generated by this project have broad applications to a variety of important disease vector control products that will benefit public health. The mosquito larvicide described is merely one application of the platform technologies and future control products directed against other insect species with aquatic life cycle stages are also feasible.  


Last Modified: 08/14/2018
Modified by: Daniel F Woods
